conclusion: Millikan oil-drop experiment involves two parallel metal plates with oil droplets falling through a hole.
Droplets A and B fall through the hole, and voltage U is applied after falling a distance h1 in time t.
Droplet A continues falling at original velocity, while B moves upward at uniform velocity.
A and B eventually merge into a single droplet.
Mass of each droplet is m0, air resistance is f = k m^(1/3)v, gravity is g, distances are h1 and h2, and time for both movements is t.
For droplet A, at terminal velocity, forces balance: m0g = k m0^(1/3)v_A, leading to v_A = m0^(2/3)g/k.
Velocity of droplet A is v_A = h1/t.
For droplet B, forces include gravity, electric force, and air resistance. At terminal velocity: q_B U/d - m0g = k m0^(1/3)v_B.
Velocity of droplet B is v_B = h2/t.
When A and B merge, mass of combined droplet is 2m0, charge is q_C = q_B.
For combined droplet, if v_C is downward: 2m0g - q_B U/d = k (2m0)^(1/3)v_C.
For combined droplet, if v_C is upward: q_B U/d - 2m0g = k (2m0)^(1/3)v_C.
From droplet B: q_B U/d - m0g = k m0^(1/3)v_B.
From droplet A's equation: k = m0^(2/3)g/v_A.
Substitute v_A = h1/t to get k = m0^(2/3)gt/h1.
From droplet B's equation: q_B U/d = m0g + k m0^(1/3)v_B.
Substitute v_B = h2/t and expression for k to get q_B U/d = m0g + m0g h2/h1.
